ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course investigates pieces of theater that have been produced and performed within the last decade or so, and asks students to dissect what makes them meaningful in the context of society, theater, etc.
How to read, watch, think, and talk about contemporary theater

Read so much excellent theater, learned about what kind of questions theater-makers ask and what different directions theater is taking these days. Also learned more about how to approach content generally, and different ways to engage as an audience member and scholar.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This class is simply structured (weekly discussions about the readings/viewings, with class discussion posts, and midterm and final papers), meaning you get to focus on the heart of the class and really get into learning from these pieces of theater. There's never any expectation that you will have completely understood the readings/viewings ahead of time, because through the discussions, you are able to learn more and share perspectives that lead to further takeaways.

Strengths - super engaging course material, great professor, cool classmates
Weaknesses - none

LOVED this class. Can't think of any weaknesses except that I wish it had been in person, and that we had gotten to go see a show together. Professor Robinson is very good at leading discussion, providing extra information while also giving students alot of room. Syllabus is great and always changing.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This class worked well in a virtual format, given that it was just a discussion! Sometimes during a long conversation, it might be hard to completely focus, but with a short break as provided part way into the seminar, the discussion was able to fall into two parts and feel manageable.
Discussion boards were very interesting and helped me get to know my peers' thoughts better.
Was very impressed with how well this seminar worked over zoom.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would highly recommend this course to any student interested in learning about new work in theater. Theater is often perceived as musicals and Shakespeare, and this class allows you to get to know so much more than that. As a class, you get to work together to understand intriguing, and sometimes difficult, pieces of theater, and the takeaways from the class discussions will stick with you as you continue to take an analytical eye on art, storytelling, and theater in the future.
YES! PROF. ROBINSON IS AMAZING and the course material is insanely cool!! Take this immediately!

1000% recommend. Fun if you are interested in pursuing theater or if you just think you are going to be watching plays in your life... I think any class with Marc Robinson is something that should be taken, but this one is especially fun and contemporary and was the only class I took this semester that felt worth taking during Covid. I feel like I came out of this class better able to appreciate creative work of all kind, inspired about the work people are doing, excited to watch and learn more. Take!
